Companies that engage in CSR activities often see improved brand reputation and customer loyalty. For example, businesses that invest in sustainable practices can attract environmentally conscious consumers. Additionally, CSR initiatives can lead to cost savings through energy efficiency and waste reduction. However, there are also challenges associated with CSR, such as the potential for increased costs and the risk of being perceived as insincere.

Firstly, CSR enhances brand reputation. Consumers today are more aware of environmental and social issues, and they prefer companies that align with their values. A strong CSR strategy can differentiate a company from its competitors, making it more attractive to customers. For instance, Patagonia, a renowned outdoor clothing brand, has built a loyal customer base through its commitment to environmental sustainability. However, implementing CSR initiatives also comes with challenges. One major challenge is the potential for increased costs. Additionally, there is a risk of being perceived as insincere if CSR efforts are seen as mere marketing tactics rather than genuine commitments. This can damage a company’s reputation and negate the positive impacts of CSR.

In conclusion, while CSR can positively impact business performance through enhanced brand reputation, customer loyalty, and operational efficiencies, it also presents challenges such as increased costs and the risk of insincerity. Moreover, fast food joints are likely to face seasonal spiked in demand – causing the workers to work extra hours during times of rush. Only when the workers love their job will they be willing to work those extra hours which their job demands them to. A lack of morale in this scenario can lead to the business remaining closed in peak sales time – such as a festival like Durga Puja – causing it to lose out on potential sales.

Low morale and welfare also might lead to high labour turnover. This will increase the costs of the business as the new workers need to be trained again. Also, the workforce relations cannot be formed as the new workers won’t feel a sense of solidarity with the business. Some customers return to fast- food joints due to familiar workers and good customer service. High labour turnover will not allow the workers to form good relations with the consumers – leading to lost potential sales again.

For instance, the recruitment process by the HRM is an important aspect of the fast food restraunt – the recruitment must not promote inequality. Recruitment based on merit will allow the business to have workers which are highly skilled and thus efficient operations – eg. the chef might be more skilled, and thus the food of the restraunt might become popular, attracting more customers.

Greater diversity in workforce, resulting from more merit-based recruitment can infuse creativity into the workforce too. For example, the chefs might come up with innovative ideas for food items – attracting more customers.

Drawing up job specification and person specification too is a vital component of a fast-food restraunt as it determines the quality of the workers hired – and hence the quality of the service provided.

A workforce planning is also important for a business in the fast-food industry. Fast food industry is often dictated by seasonal spiked in demand. A good workforce planning can lead the HR managers knowing the times when extra workers might be needed, and hence preparing beforehand by hiring part time workers. Moreover, since the labour in a fast food restraunt are likely to be semi-skilled, the ethical (or not) nature of the recruitment process won’t significantly determine the quality of service.
